Actually, antimatter wasn't always so "rare". There was almost as much of antimatter as of matter, very close to 50-50%. The reason why we see that the matter in the entire Universe is matter and not antimatter is that we only see what's left after almost the entire emount of matter and antimatter annihilated each other after the moment of the Big Bang.
Let's say, 2×10^90 particles were created. ~10^90 matter, ~10^90 antimatter, close to 50-50%.
But for each 10 billion (10^10) antimatter particles, there was 10 billion +1 matter particle. Seems like a very little difference. However, after equal amounts of matter and antimatter annihilated each other, there was 10^80 matter particles left and that is the matter of our Universe.
The question that needs to be answered, more precisely, is not "why is antimatter so rare"; but "why was that tiny little difference in the amount of matter and antimatter created in the big bang". In other words, it isn't the "rarity of antimatter" that needs explanation, as there is nothing surprising in the absence of antimatter within a whole universe made of matter. It's the little surplus of matter that is still unexplained.

Like, the electron resonates within the electromagnetic field generating a rippling wave of which its integral is the energy density of one electron:  -1.602 x 10^(-19) Amperes of current strength over the observed time span of One Second. The proton vibrates exactly 180 degrees out of phase to the electron generating the energy density of PLUS 1.602 x 10^(-19) Ampere Seconds. Antimatter therefore must vibrate with exactly mirrored energy to its counterpart. The overlaying of the energy waves would cancel them, "deleting" matter. Kinda like the double slit experiment where, when maximum and minimum of the standing wave combine, the result is bright and dark spots when observing the wave characteristic of light. I mean, it seems fairly simple as to why we wouldn't see much antimatter from our perspective. Matter likes to cluster together, and so too should antimatter. The energy from annihilations as well as general expansion would push these matter-antimatter pairs further and further apart, perhaps on a galactic or multigalactic scale over time, where there would be little to no chance of mass annihilations, and thus little to no chance of us finding equal amounts of antimatter and matter. Assuming our theories about there being equal amounts of the two are correct, there could be entire galaxies and galactic clusters made up entirely of antimatter, pushed trillions of light years or more away from their matter counterparts simply because of their unstable nature when together.

I was chillin' with Hawking back in the nineties in Ft. Lauderdale during Spring Break one year when we were getting pretty buzzed at a nighttime bonfire. We're talking about the whole matter - antimatter balance thing when I come up with this concept of Matter-Antimatter Encapsulation in Mirrored Dimensions. We experience the Universe and all its matter as a contiguous space, which we associate with being a massive sphere. Expanding or not, for that matter sphere to be balanced by antimatter, the antimatter would need to encapsulate the matter like the foam in a fitted equipment case hugs the equipment it protects. But we observe no evidence of this, so we abandon it.

But what if we didn't? What if, instead, we consider that there might be a corresponding "antidimension" in which the antimatter resides? The necessary interactions between matter and antimatter may occur as needed, but we observe these interactions ONLY from the third dimension (and fourth, when observed over time) with which we are familiar -- THAT'S why we can only observe the EFFECTS of antimatter, but not antimatter itself.

So as far as matter is concerned, it IS balanced by antimatter, just not visibly for us, and vice-versa for antimatter. The dimension and antidimension interact outside our ability to observe their interaction, yet they remain in perfect balance.

And then, when you fold this model in on itself, what do you get?

A wormhole.

Antimatter is NOT the rarest "substance", not at all, it's not even rare either. Antimatter is supposed to exist in almost the same amount as there is normal matter. Yes there is a subtle imbalance, however, in theory there is a particle of antimatter to any particle of matter, antiquarks - quarks, anti electrons (positrons) - electrons. The thing is, that positrons, anitmatter, only have extremely short lifespans, hence, they are almost impossible to capture, not even to mention the difficulties in containing them. In conclusion: Just because we cannot store or create considerable amounts of permanent/semi-permanent forms of antimatter doesn't mean there isn't a lot of it. Positrons get annihilated quickly, but as matter, antimatter cannot simply disappear. There is enormous amounts of antimatter out there, yet we can't really use or handle it the same way we do with conventional matter.

Foreword: I dropped out of school to work after grade10 so i'm sort of assuming that if 1 type of matter has an opposite anti matter therefore every type of matter must have an opposite too so here's something to tickle everyone's thinking pickle:
-Maybe the reason anti-matter is so difficult to find/detect is because instead of the common thought that when all forms of matter and anti-matter come into contact they annihilate each other immediately in a big flash of light: The speed of the reaction between the two opposite forms of matter is determined by the structural volatility of the type of matter in question.
i.e. the speed at which hydrogen and anti-hydrogen cancel each other out compared to the speed of a more stable element and it's opposite.
In other words: Everything hasn't cancelled itself out yet because it's still a work in-progress. In the event that a type of particle and it's anti particle can't cancel each other instantly, they form a sort of symbiotic fight to the death relationship that we observe as varying forms of decay and aging.

I've always wondered if the english "too small" numbers continue beyond trillion, and apparently they do. For us million is 10^6, billion = 10^12, trillion = 10^18, quadrillion = 10^24 etc. We have a special word for 10^9, "milliard", but you call that billion, and our billion is your trillion. So apparently you call our trillion a quintillion and our quadrillion a septillion. The scale of potential error is impressive :-)

This is not antimatter, it is an "anti-proton." An anti-proton is made from matter by alpha-decay of the positron out of the nucleus. No one has ever tried to put any of this stuff back together to see if it annihilates.
Why would "anti-matter" annihilate by putting it back together as matter, makes no sense, since antiprotons came from matter and it was perfectly stable before we pulled the anti-proton out of the matter. As a matter of fact, anti-matter decays back into matter within just a few seconds, by beta-decay, if not contained in a strong magnetic field. That is why there is not much anti-matter in the universe. Anti-matter does not exist and is impossible, they are just labeling it anti-matter, with no such evidence that it will annihilate when put back together as matter.
Also we alpha-decay a positron out of matter, then an electron beta-decays out of "anti-matter" to make matter again. That means a positron and an electron where both existing together inside of matter before it alpha and beta decayed out an electron and a positron, so clearly those can exist together in the nucleus and they do not annihilate anything when together as matter.
Also we they smash a photon into the nucleus of an atom, they can get the two to separate out of the photon into an electron and a positron, so clearly they can exist together as a photon without annihilating.

Anti-protons and protons are mixed together all the time in the Van Allen Belts and at the center of Marklund convection in the inter-galactic filaments, and none of it has ever shown evidence of annihilation. In fact the evidence is that at the axis of flow of Marklund convection, twists protons and anti-protons twist back together as neutral matter, yet no evidence of annihilation anywhere. Nor have they ever tried it in a lab, just playing around with busted up chunks of matter.

As I understand it (but I'm only an engineer, you have the MIT Physics degree), antimatter doesn't exist naturally in spacetime because it all self-annihilated during the quark-lepton phase of the Big Bang with all normal matter at the time in the quark/antiquark soup of the fledgling universe for a very brief moment... except for perhaps one-billionth of the time there was an extra quark made (for reasons we don't understand?) that couldn't re-annihilate because it couldn't find a complimentary partner to "merge" with (I think we've all been there). After a few millionths of a second or so the universe cooled enough that random interactions were separated enough to allow those rare "normal" quarks to remain without annihilating with anything. Hence, matter became extremely common as the only survivor, and antimatter virtually extinct naturally (as far as we know). So, since we have to make it completely ourselves in tiny little amounts, antimatter is essentially the rarest thing in the universe now.

Everything that is matter is everything within our plain of existence. So what would be “anti-matter” is literally the antithesis of what is existence which means it does not actually exist. Consider:
* Nuclear fission/fusion releases energy proportional to the mass difference between a proton and a neutron -- on the order of an electron -- which is miniscule.

* Antimatter/matter annihilation releases energy proportional to the mass of . . . whole atomic nuclei.

In other words, antimatter has millions of times the destructive potential, per atom, as nuclear bombs.

Anyhow, back on track with my train of thought, it seems clear why the universe does not contain macro- amounts of both matter and antimatter. It can't. One of the two HAD to dominate. Locally, I suppose it would be possible for either to dominate, at least temporarily. If some of the energy released in matter-antimatter annihilation ultimately reappears as matter (or anti-), then the incompatibility should continue to be thrashed out until one or the other is entirely depleted. It seems unlikely that the ultimate winner should be decided randomly, because the two forms of matter aren't really chiral. Some of the fundamental laws of the universe show "handedness"— electromagnetism — which must, in some as yet mysterious sequence account for the apparent chiral anomaly of matter-antimatter. The cosmos may show a subtle preference for how reality sorts itself out, perhaps revealing subtle bias in some putative symmetries.

So this stuff causes problems when it comes in contact with any matter - how were they able to store it for up to 400 days? And if they can store it, why are they not able to move it? Granted the storage might not be exactly portable, but that's more a practical problem than a theoretical physics one. I wonder if this could have any practical uses, possibly as energy storage or production, maybe even space travel (antimatter engines, I'm sure that's been mentioned in some sci-fi), or (horrifyingly) in warfare? Would seem not from the current situation, but that doesn't mean that won't change - radioactivity started in a similar manner, first a physics curiosity, and later a major power source and weapons, all in under a century if I understand right. I also wonder if maybe there's antimatter elsewhere in the universe, or in a different universe, that isn't too different from ours except being built of antimatter instead of normal matter, but we have yet to find it. Or maybe it's so similar to matter that, so long as it doesn't come in contact with matter, they're in some ways indistinguishable, and some distant galaxies we've already spotted are actually antimatter, we just don't know it yet.

The title of this video kills me.
The title is mostly confusing because we have an well american accent speaking person talking so you'd think they would use the American Name, but it reads as the British Name more than the American Name. It could mean different things depending if you're using the American Name or British name to read these numbers.


For example;
10^9
American = Billion
British = Thousand Million


10^12
American = Trillion
British = Billion


10^15
American = Quadrillion (What the Title means to read as)
British = Thousand Billion

10^18
American = Quintillion
British = Trillion


10^21
American = Sextillion
British = Thousand Trillion (What the Title actually reads as)


Source:
https://www.britannica.com/topic/large-numbers-1765137

Some perspective on how difficult antimatter is to make:

Antimatter can be produced in high energy collisions that produce pairs of particles and antiparticles, but these pairs attract each other really strongly and want to recombine right fast, unless you can neutralise them, which poses it's own challenges.

How strongly?

If you produced a gram of antiprotons this way, and a corresponding gram of protons, and put them on opposite sides of the earth to each other, these two samples would still be attracting each other....

...With a force of over 7 metric tons, from the other side of the planet!

The easy answer to why there is so little anti-matter in the universe is annihilation.  If you have two substances that annihilate each other, and you put them together, unless the initial volumes were exactly equal, then the two substances would destroy each other until the one with more initial volume is left in the end.  This means there had to be more matter than anti-matter initially, and this also means the initial volume of matter could have potentially been much greater than there is left over now.

I don't know why the universe seems to contain so little antimatter - but I have a fan theory. If the Feynman-Stueckelberg Interpretation is real, then during baryogenesis when time itself was beginning to have meaning in the nascent universe (since bosons don't experience time like baryons do), the baryons that formed were about 50% antimatter, and the antimatter baryons were moving backwards in time. There would have been significant collisions between the forward-moving matter and backward-moving antimatter, but the energy released from an antiparicle colliding would have resulted in another 50% toss-up, and so on. It would mean the universe is a four-dimensional hourglass shape, with the throat of the hourglass being the diameter of the universe at the start of baryogenesis. The big bang, as it were, went boom in both directions of time - it is the singular big bang AND the singular big crunch. Just a fan theory....

The part about antimatter possibly falling upward got me thinking, and I thought I'd share my thoughts. Half, if not most of this is unrelated but I thought it was interesting:

If antimatter had negative mass then when you tried to push a positron into a container with a positively charged plate, it wouldn't work. This is because of f=ma, or a=f/m, if you try to repel the positron into said container with a positively charged plate, the negative mass actually makes the acceleration negative as well, so the positron heads towards the plate. As this does not happen, we know they don't have negative mass.

Negative masses also still fall in normal gravity, however. f=mg, so the negative mass means the object is pushed by gravity.
But again, as a=f/m, the negative mass means this pushing force accelerates the object toward the positive mass.
So the reason for antimatter falling upward wouldn't be negative mass, but some other property.

As far as I can tell, negative mass must be impossible. This is because while positive masses attract negative ones, negative masses repel positive ones. The pushing force exerted by the positive mass on the negative one must, by Newton's laws, mean that the negative mass exerts a pushing force of equal magnitude on the positive mass. As its mass is positive, it is indeed repelled.

So we have an object being repelled by another object, which is itself being attracted to the first. They will follow each other, accelerating ad infinitum. Now let's attach this system to the end of a pole, with a generator in the middle. Infinite free energy as the two follow each other in a loop, turning the generator to produce energy. Infinite free energy is of course impossible as per the laws of thermodynamics, and so negative mass must be too.

I could be wrong, so look it up if you're interested.
